Situation1: They are expected to be present at a family dinner or small gathering.
Situation2: Got a request to attend court to provide testimony when required.
Story:
I stared at my phone, the screen lighting up with a reminder: “Family dinner at 7.” My stepbrother had texted earlier, asking if I could help set the table and maybe stay late to play cards with everyone. It was one of those rare evenings when everyone would be together, and I knew how much it meant to my stepmom that I showed up, participated, and made an effort to bond. 

But just as I was about to reply, my work phone buzzed. The message was short and urgent: “Court testimony required, 7:30 PM. Your presence is mandatory.” As a police officer, I knew the importance of showing up in court—my testimony could make or break a case. Integrity and fairness were at the core of my job, and skipping out wasn’t an option if I wanted to do right by the badge I wore.

I felt the pressure building inside me, torn between the family that wanted me present and the duty that demanded my honesty and commitment. My heart pounded as I weighed the disappointment in my stepmom’s eyes against the trust the justice system placed in me. I sat there, phone in hand, paralyzed by the impossible choice.
